Step 3.4: Configure a cluster witness
We recommend that you configure a witness for the cluster, so clusters with three or more servers can withstand two servers failing or being offline. A two-server deployment requires a cluster witness, otherwise either server going offline causes the other to become unavailable as well. With these systems, you can use a file share as a witness, or use cloud witness.

Storage Spaces Direct (S2D) requires a minimum of four servers for the cluster. The four servers are used to create a quorum, which helps to ensure high availability of the storage. Without a quorum, data loss or corruption may occur if one of the servers in the cluster fails.
Additionally, using a Cloud witness is an optional feature that can be used to provide an additional witness vote when using a stretched cluster, it does not affect the minimum number of virtual machines required for the cluster.

according to chatgpt: 
--If I were to deploy Storage Spaces Direct to a cluster that will store FSLogix profile containers and this cluster will NOT use Cloud witness. What is the minimum number of virtual machines required for the cluster?

The minimum number of virtual machines required for a Storage Spaces Direct cluster that will store FSLogix profile containers and will not use a Cloud witness is four. This is because Storage Spaces Direct requires a minimum of three nodes to provide fault tolerance and data availability. Additionally, a fourth node is required to serve as a file server for the FSLogix profile containers.
Note that this is a minimal setup and it's recommended to have more nodes for better performance and availability.

Storage Spaces Direct is a software-defined storage solution that allows you to share storage resources in your converged and hyperconverged IT infrastructure. It enables you to combine internal storage drives on a cluster of physical servers (2 and up to 16) into a software-defined pool of storage. This storage pool has cache, tiers, resiliency, and erasure coding across columns—all configured and managed automatically.
